The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.

A permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$ is called a cycle if there exist distinct elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}$ in $\{1, \ldots, n\}, r \geq 2$, such that $\pi(x_{i}) = x_{i+1}$ for $1 \leq i < r$, $\pi(x_{r}) = x_{1}$, and $\pi(x) = x$ for $x \in \{1, \ldots, n\} - \{x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r}\}$.
Does the concept of a/an Symmetric Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Cycle to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Cycle explicitly references the symmetric group, denoted as \(\mathfrak{S}_{n}\). A cycle is defined as a permutation \(\pi\) that belongs to \(\mathfrak{S}_{n}\), which is the symmetric group on \(n\) elements. The symmetric group \(\mathfrak{S}_{n}\) is defined as the group of all bijective self-maps of the set \(\{1, \ldots, n\}\). Without the concept of the symmetric group, the definition of a cycle would lack context because it wouldn't be clear what set \(\pi\) is a permutation of, or what properties such a permutation should have. Therefore, the concept of the symmetric group is necessary to fully understand and define what a cycle is in the context of permutations.
